metadata.title: Machine Learning: From Ideation to a Web App | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Machine Learning: From Ideation to a Web App
metadata.description: An End-to-End Data Science Journey of Data Collection, Web Scraping, Data Cleaning, Model Training, and Cloud Deployment Using Python and Flask

all_paragraphs: All of my previous posts on practical ML aspects have mostly centered around a single topic of the ML pipeline in your Data Science journey. Here, however, I will aim to take you through the entire end-to-end journey starting from data collection and ending with a cloud-deployed ML model that can be accessed by anyone from anywhere.

Other than the usual suspects of data munging, feature engineering, feature selection, model training, and validation, we will also see how to perform web scraping (through BeautifulSoup), together with deploying an ML model on Heroku using Flask. I hope to take you through a practical data science journey highlighting some of the relatively non-sexy and time-consuming tasks of an ML project.
Our aim in this project will be to predict the winner of a One Day International (ODI) Cricket match between any two countries, i.e., a classification problem.
For those who are not familiar with cricket, the game works as follows:
Once we have a trained model, we will:

Our primary data source will be the four datasets related to men’s ODIs publicly available here. This data was scraped from Cricinfo’s Statsguru and included essential details on all the ODIs from the first ODI in January 1971 up to March 2020. The four CSVs have the following necessary information of each game:
We will concatenate these dataframes together in the data munging phase. Despite the rich information available in these files, they are still missing some other critical information as follows:

Web scraping is the process of extracting information from websites and storing them in your local computer or ingested in your code. Python boasts multiple web scraping libraries that allow us to utilize raw data from a website as part of your python code. We will use BeautifulSoup for this purpose as it is simple enough to use while boasting several advanced functionalities related to text manipulation and parsing.

BeautifulSoup works by taking a website and then parsing its HTML elements into a BeautifulSoup object. We can then extract a specific text based on its location within the BeautifulSoup object using HTML tags and its tree-like structure. For example, BeautifulSoup can help us to:
Some basic knowledge of HTML is required to understand a web site’s structure, the HTML tags used, and how to play around with a specific web site’s HTML tags using BeautifulSoup.
Each ODI on Howstat has a unique Match Code in that match’s URL. We will use these unique match codes in a for loop to scrape the following information for every ODI ever played:

Match date and Ground Name will be used to match and merge the toss result with our primary dataset of match details. The relevant information as present on the website looks like this — which is consistent across all matches:

Through a bit of trial and error, I determined the match codes on Howstat (mostly sequential) and saved them in a CSV file. Once this CSV is uploaded as a dataframe, we will go through each match code in a for loop to scrape the required information from each match’s Howstat scorecard and save as a separate dataframe. The premise is simple:
And there you have it, a dataframe comprising of toss information of all the ODIs ever played, albeit the text scrapped still needs some cleaning.
Code for steps performed so far:
We will now undertake certain data cleaning, preprocessing, and merging tasks to prepare our data for eventual ingestion into a classification algorithm.

We will clean the ODI_results dataframe first that holds the high-level details of each game. Take note of its structure: each game has two records: one from each playing team’s perspective. So, for example, if England won a match against Australia on a particular day, then this match will have the following two records:

Also, note that the dataframe does not have the Opposition country’s name as a separate column. Instead, it is bundled up with the Match column like this: Team 1 v Team 2. We will perform the following steps:
Now we will tackle our ODI_innings dataframe, which requires a lot more cleaning to do. Let us first understand its structure:
Some issues that I noticed during manual EDA:
The data cleaning tasks, which are similar to what we performed on ODI_results, include:

Now we should merge or join our two cleaned dataframes into one. Our objective here is to add twenty-four columns to the ODI_results_clean dataframe with the names of each of the twelve players from both the playing and opposition teams in their respective columns:

The above data structure ensures that we have each game’s data in a single row. It is a rather tricky process that involves multiple merge and unstack operations, but I will try my best to explain my approach:
Code for data munging operations performed so far:
Next up is the last bit of web scraping to get the ICC ODI ranks of all players as of the match date from the official ICC ODI Rankings website. A high-level workflow to achieve this is as follows:
For each unique date on which an ODI was played:

At the end of the for loop, we will have a list of multiple dataframes with player names, bowling, and batting ranks as of each date when an ODI was played. The final step will be a simple concatenation of this list to result in a comprehensive final dataframe (final_result) comprising of the following information across 7,738 rows and 78 columns:
Next up is to clean our toss_df dataframe and merge it with ODI_matches dataframe. Some high-level tasks include:
Code for the next bit of data munging tasks follows:
We already have quite a lot of information to develop a predictive working model with, but we can add and evaluate some more.
I would expect the weather to play a part in the outcome of an ODI match. We can add the month of the year as a proxy for this bit of information.
This is the ratio of the number of cumulative matches won by a country to the games lost by it at any given date. We can quickly determine this from the information we have collected so far.
Next up, we will calculate the following four new features for each team based on the innings level information that we have in our original ODI_innings dataframe:
These four features will be calculated for each country based on its cumulative statistics up to, but not including, that match date. The relevant columns required to calculate them are:

We only have five of the six features we require to calculate the four new features since we are missing Innings Wickets Taken by a team in a game. But this can be easily calculated since we have the Innings Wickets Taken by the opposition for each match. Wickets lost by a team are equivalent to wickets taken by the opposition.

Then once we have all the six columns required to calculate the four new features, we will loop over all the countries to calculate the cumulative values of these six variables for each country up to, but not including the match date. Once we have the cumulative statistics, we’re only left with calculating the four new features. Our new dataframe will look something like this:
Next up, we will drop all but the last four columns and merge with the final_data dataframe.

We can also update the Toss Won By column to something like Toss Won? to indicate whether the playing team won the toss or not. This will convert the column to a binary format and eliminate the potential sparse dataframe through dummy/one-hot encoding.

Remember that, for some games, we have twelve players (due to player substitution during the game), but for our model training and predictions, we cannot have more than eleven players. This is because a team can’t have more than eleven playing members before a game starts.
To accommodate this, and for only those matches with twelve players in our dataset, we will update any one player’s rank to be equal to the average ranks of all twelve players as of the Match Date.

We are almost towards the end of our feature-engineering but maybe let’s try something additional as well. Currently, we have a total of 44 ranking columns for each match — this might be a bit too much that could result in the ‘curse of dimensionality’. What if we can summarize each team’s batting & bowling ranks information in a single column? This can potentially cut down the number of ranking columns from 44 to 4.

But before doing this, we should impute the missing ranks. Missing ranks are due to players that are not in the top 100 ICC ODI Ranking listing as at the date of the match, i.e., their ranking is higher than 100. I will go with a constant 101 to replace missing ranks. You can try some other constants, but I believe this to be most appropriate as a higher constant might result in misinterpretation due to being somewhat of an outlier.

We can select any descriptive statistic to represent the 11 players’ batting and bowling information as long as a layperson can quickly calculate it during predictions. I will calculate sum, mean, and median and evaluate further during feature selection.
We are now done with all of our feature engineering, which resulted in fourteen new features.
All the code for feature engineering activities follows:
Refer to my previous article for a refresher on the feature selection techniques that I will utilize here.
Performing a chi-squared test to determine whether our categorical features are related to the target variable results in the following:

Clearly surprising result we got here — I would have expected the toss outcome and the ground to have a material impact on the match outcome. However, given the data that we have on hand, this does not seem to be the case given their high p-values.
We can potentially run the model validation metrics both with and without these two features and take it from there. But for this project, we will drop these features before model training.
Running an ANOVA F-statistic test on the numerical features results in the following insights:

Hence I will discard all the 12 additional features that describe the players’ ranks and were created in the last feature engineering (together with the Match Month) and continue our modeling with individual players’ ranks.
The code for feature selection follows:
Finally, we come to the fun bit of machine learning — model training. We will use a simple Logistic Regression algorithm to make our predictions.

I had also tried specific other algorithms (e.g., XGBoost, Random Forest, Ada Boost, Gradient Boosting), but other than the Random Forest, the other three did not result in a material improvement in the prediction accuracy.
After dropping the columns based on feature selection steps, we simply need to create dummy variables from the categorical features before fitting a logistic regression model.

For comprehensive model evaluation, we will perform RepeatedStratifiedkFold cross-validation with ten folds repeated thrice and with Accuracy as our evaluation metric since our data is not imbalanced.

Our mean Accuracy score comes at 68.66% — a reasonable, if not outstanding, accuracy. But I guess this was to be expected given the game’s nature where an individual brilliance on the day can turn a match from a losing position to a winning position for a team.
We can also draw a ROC curve and determine the appropriate probability threshold to differentiate between expected win and loss.
Using Youden’s J-Statistic, our ideal probability threshold comes to 48.27%, i.e., this threshold will result in a maximum discriminatory power to differentiate between expected wins and losses.
Our final step will be to simply pickle the model to enable predictions through our web app (Final_LR_Model.pkl).
All the modeling and validation related code is:

So how do we now make predictions using our model? There are a couple of ways to do it: we can pass in the features to the model and call the predict or predict_proba method, or we can share the pickled file with others to predict themselves ( so long as they know their way around python).

But both these methods require human intervention to load data and pass it through the model. What if we want to open our model for the world and allow anyone, anytime, to make their predictions without any direct interactions with python and other technical tasks?

To achieve this, we can develop a website to capture user input, pass it to a Flask back-end for preprocessing and predictions, and return the model output to the user through another web page. Essentially, we want something like this — which is our model deployed on the cloud, making it accessible to the world and requires zilch knowledge of python, machine learning, etc.

Developing a website requires some level of HTML and CSS style sheets’ knowledge, which is outside the scope of this article. However, you don’t need to be an expert to design a simple input form. Several free online platforms and software provide templates or allow HTML development through a simple drag and drop interface.

The HTML code tells a browser what to display on the screen while the CSS file tells it how to display the HTML content on screen. CSS is an efficient way of controlling a web page’s layout by specifying background color, font size & color, margins, etc.
Please refer to the HTML and CSS code for our web app and take note of the following particular points:
Example code to define a drop-down:
Example code to define a text field for integers (e.g. a player’s bowling rank):
Example code to define a text field for floats (e.g. batting average):
Let’s go over some main elements of these tags:

We will develop the back-end of our web application using a Flask framework. Think of Flask as a library that you can import just like any other library in Python. So basically, our application will be a simple Python file (with a .py extension, and not a notebook with a .ipynb extension) that utilizes Flask in addition to all other Python functionalities.
The code for our back-end application is as follows:
I tried my best to comment well in order to make the above code self-explanatory but let’s go over it on a high-level:

But let’s first test our app locally before deploying it into the cloud. Fire up Anaconda Prompt (or any terminal of your choice), navigate to the folder that has app.py, Final_LR_Model.pkl, and templates & static folders, and run it using:
Ignore the version conflict version (you might not see it), open the URL in your web browser. You should see your pretty home.html and be able to enter test values and make predictions.
Congratulations! you have now built your first ML app. Next, we will take this application from your local machine into the cloud so other people can use it with a URL.
Heroku offers Platform as a Service (PaaS) for cloud deployments. There are several ways to complete a Heroku deployment, but the simplest is probably through a GitHub repository.
Other than the two files and two folders that we used while testing our app locally, we need two more files in our GitHub repository before Heroku deployment:

You should be quite familiar with all requirements above. Think of Gunicorn as a middleware that allows your Flask application to communicate with the server on which it is hosted. Technically speaking, it is a Python Web Server Gateway Interface (WSGI) HTTP server
At this stage, your GitHub repository should look something like this:
Follow the following steps to complete your Heroku deployment:
A partial look at our application accessible over the internet:
There you have it — a complete working machine learning model developed in Python and deployed on the cloud, accessible by anyone round the clock!
This was a pretty whirlwind tour, and I hope you would have stuck with me throughout while also learning some new concepts, tools, techniques, and methodologies along the way.
You can also find the complete notebook here.
Feel free to reach out to me if you would like to discuss anything related to data analytics, machine learning, financial or credit analysis.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
A finance professional by education with a keen interest in data analytics and machine learning. www.finltyicshub.com
